passages.text: August 29, 2025 04:00 AM GMT
Siemens Energy AG (ENR1n.DE) Price Target

We stay Overweight ENR (Top Pick) and GEV. Both will issue new mid-term guidance in 2H25, an important marker for future margin potential. Looking at consensus, we see more scope for ENR to surprise positively with its targets, but we still see continued positive EPS momentum ahead for both stocks

We think ENR's new targets will imply a 2028 EBITA 11% ahead of sell- side consensus. For GEV, we expect new targets more to 'cover' consensus. Higher GEV 'buyside' expectations with Power / Electrification EBITDA margins now viewed at c23% in 2028. ENR Gas / Grid expectations are c20% (EBITDA). Other CMD strategy debates: 1) Gas turbine capacity additions, 2) Shareholder returns, 3) Long- term wind strategy, 4) Signals on post 2028 demand / margins. Valuation: ENR trades on 7.7x 2028e EV/EBITDA, and GEV on 18.5x. ENR is also on 2028e EV/EBITA of 9.2x, a 20% discount to the EU Cap Goods sector.

Exhibit 1: Absolute EBITA for Siemens Energy and EBITDA for GE Vernova: We think the midpoint of new 2028- ENR guidance (assumed at 14% EBITA margins) could drive 11% upgrades to consensus. Our base case for GEV is new guidance of 18% 2028 EBITDA margins - more in line with existing consensus.
\*Note. The range of buyside expectations shown is approximate only, informed by our conversations with investors. Source: Visible Alpha consensus, Morgan Stanley Research estimates
MORGAN STANLEY & CO. INTERNATIONAL PLC+
Max R Yates Equity Analyst

Backdrop: Both Siemens Energy and GE Vernova will give new mid- term targets later this year – Siemens Energy with its FY25 results on 14th November, followed by its CMD in the US on 19th- 20th November; GE Vernova will address its mid- term targets later in the year with a separate investor event likely in December, similar to 2024. Pre- existing targets for mid- term targets are for 2028, and it is unclear at this stage whether both companies will update the 2028 guidance or roll the guidance forward to 2029 or 2030. For the purposes of this report, we are working off the assumption that the updated guidance will remain for 2028, and this is what we assume is the most likely outcome for Siemens Energy's new guidance. We lay out in detail, by division, what we expect in Exhibit 2.

So far both companies have preferred to remain on the more conservative side in their guidance. This has allowed both companies to enjoy significant positive earnings revisions for 2028. Siemens Energy's 2028 consensus EBITDA has increased by 27% so far this year (vs a 82% YTD share price increase), and GE Vernova's 2028 consensus EBITDA has risen by 25% in the same period (vs an 85% YTD share price increase). What is clear from the re- ratings, and the favourable end- market dynamics, is that investor expectations in both cases have run ahead of the sell- side consensus. From our perspective, we do not look at the new guidance as representing the maximum potential on profitability for either stock. Instead, we think both companies will continue to seek a balance between managing investor expectations while also giving themselves room to continue to 'beat and raise' in the next 12- 24 months. That said, based on our conversations with investors, our clear sense is that expectations for GE Vernova appear more elevated than what appears to be is assumed for Siemens Energy (Exhibit 2).

Siemens Energy – what do we expect for the new mid- term targets? Bottom line, we expect Siemens Energy to increase group 2028 EBITA margin guidance to 13- 15% (from 10- 12% currently). We also think group organic revenue CAGR will

remain at high single digit to low double digit, though we expect the growth guidance for the Gas services division to be increased to low double digit. Current 2028 consensus sits at 13% EBITA margins, and our estimates are for 14.4%. As we show in Exhibit 1, we expect a new 2028 EBITA margin guidance range of 13%- 15%, implying 2028 EBITA of €7.3bn. This is 11% ahead of current consensus of €6.6bn.
We think the key drivers of the guidance upgrade are: 1) Gas EBITA margins

moving to 16- 18% (from 12- 14%) which at the midpoint implies that Siemens Energy continues to see 50bps margin expansion per year in 2026- 28; and 2) 2028 Grid margin guidance increasing to 17- 19% (from 13- 15%). To put this into perspective, we expect Siemens Energy to already generate Grid margins of 16% in 2025, or 15% for 2025 excluding the positive one- off. Essentially the midpoint of our expected new guidance for Grid margins would imply this division can see a further 100bps margin increase per year in 2026- 28.

GE Vernova – what do we expect for the new mid- term targets? We expect GEV to increase its 2028 consolidated EBITDA guidance by 400bps to 18% (from 14% currently). We also expect a higher revenue base, as we think the company will raise consolidated revenue guidance to \(\) 50bn\(from\) \ \(45bn / HSD\) organic growth). Consensus 2028 EBITDA margin estimate and our model are both \~18%, approximately in line with where we expect GEV to guide in December. Consensus

revenue ( \(\) 49bn) is slightly lower than MSE ( \(\) 50bn) and slightly lower where we think the company could guide (Exhibit 2). This would imply roughly \(\) 9bn of EBITDA based on potential new guidance, similar to consensus of \(\) 8bn (2\%\$ above). Strength in Power and Electrification are the primary underlying factors influencing our conviction in a positive guidance revision. At the segment level we expect GEV to raise its 2028 Power EBITDA margin outlook to 20% (from 16%), roughly in line with consensus and MSE. Similarly in Electrification we think GEV will guide to 20% (from 16%) segment margins by 2028, in line with consensus and MSE, and \~500bps higher than what we expect for 2025.

Siemens Energy. We would stress that collating buy- side expectations is an approximate exercise, but nonetheless we think it can be a helpful addition to the debate for both stocks. Based on our conversations with investors, our view is that buyside expectations for GE Vernova's Power divisional EBITDA margins appear to have run to around 22%- 25%, with Power expectations running slightly above Electrification at 22- 24% (we would not signal too much precision here, but generally our sense is that investors see more pricing upside ahead in Gas Power and thus higher margin potential). Siemens Energy reports EBITA margins, but we think converting Siemens Energy's margins to EBITDA implies that the buyside is EBITDA margins in the region of c20% for the Siemens Energy Gas and Grid divisions in 2028 (18- 19% EBITDA).

From our perspective, when we listen to the tone of conference calls, we find that the GE Vernova management team have been more upbeat on the mid- term margin opportunity, and the pricing environment. On the one hand this has opened up a debate in the market on whether GE Vernova's pricing dynamics on orders, particularly in Gas turbines, are more positive than what Siemens Energy is seeing. On the other hand, we think this debate has kept more of a lid on buy- side expectations, and ultimately we think it gives more room for Siemens Energy's new mid- term targets, which will be issued on 14th November, to be a positive catalyst for the stock. Ultimately, when we look at quantitative evidence so far (Exhibit 3 to Exhibit 6) we can see Siemens Energy's Gas services margins are broadly in line with GEV's Power margins, and Siemens Energy's Grid margins are ahead of GEV's Electrification margins.

We think the other key debates that the market will be looking out for are: 1) Capacity additions - at what point would GEV or Siemens Energy expand Gas turbine capacity further? We expect both companies to remain relatively reserved on this, and we would be surprised if Siemens Energy committed to re- opening its mothballed US Gas turbine facility. 2) Additional shareholder returns - we expect Siemens Energy to restart the dividend at the end of 2025, but we do not expect any additional shareholder returns to be announced until the end of 2027. GEV also sits on a strong net cash position and is positioned to generate substantial FCF through 2028e. 3) Wind strategy - we do not expect anything to be announced in the short term, as both companies remain committed to turning around profitability in their respective divisions. However, the willingness of both companies to continue to participate in these markets will remain under scrutiny by investors. For Siemens

consensus estimates. We expect the midpoint of Siemens Energy's new targets will be 11% ahead of current consensus EBITA.

2. We expect GEV to increase its 2028 consolidated EBITDA guidance by 400bps to 18% (from 14% currently). We also expect a higher revenue base, as we think the company will raise consolidated revenue guidance to \(\) 50bn\(from\) \ \(45bn / HS\) D organic growth). Consensus 2028 EBITDA margin estimate and our model are both \(\sim 18\%\) approximately in line with where we expect GEV to guide in December.

3. Higher consensus expectations for GEV vs Siemens Energy. It is notable that consensus estimates for EBITDA margins for GEV's Power and Electrification divisions are already above consensus estimates for EBITA margins for ENR's gas and grid divisions. Once adjusted for depreciation, we think GEV's consensus margins for these divisions are 200-300bps higher than what is in consensus for Siemens Energy's respective divisions.

4. Siemens Energy has achieved its pre-existing 2028 guidance in 2025. For Siemens Energy, while the guidance increases are optically large for Gas and Grid, we should consider that Gas margins will already be close to 12.5%-13% in 2025. For Grid margins, we forecast 16% in 2025; adjusted for a positive one-off, this would be 15%. Effectively, to get to the midpoint of the new 2028 EBITA margin ranges that we expect Siemens Energy to set, it would need 150bps of margin expansion per year in Gas in 2026-28 and 100bps per year in Grid.

Exhibit 3: Power sales growth: Siemens Energy's Gas turbine sales growth guidance (11- 13%) is ahead of GE Vernova's guidance of 6- 7% organic revenue growth for its Power division. Our forecasts imply that Siemens Energy's sales growth will remain above GEVs
Source: Company Data, Morgan Stanley Research estimates

Exhibit 4: Power margins: We see EBITA margins improving on a similar trajectory. We think that if we adjust GEV's Power margins from EBITDA to EBITA, they are on a similar level to Siemens Energy's Gas services margins in 2025
Source: Company Data, Morgan Stanley Research estimates

**Exhibit 5:** Grid sales growth: In 2024-25, Siemens Energy's sales growth is somewhat ahead of GE Vernova's. In 2025, Siemens Energy is guiding to Grid technology organic revenue growth of 24%- 26%, which is ahead of GEV's Electrification divisional guidance of 20%
Source: Company Data, Morgan Stanley Research estimates

**Exhibit 6:** Grid margins: Siemens Energy's margin execution has surprised positively in 2025, and its margins (EBITA) on a comparable basis are running slightly ahead of GE Vernova. Hitachi Energy's Adjusted EBITA margin target is 13-15% in 2027, which compares to our forecast of Siemens Energy reaching 17.5% EBITA margins for its Grid division in 2027
Source: Company Data, Morgan Stanley Research estimates

The decline in Gas demand since 'Dash- for- Gas' in the 1990s is well known, and the idea that demand for Large Gas Turbines is in secular decline had become the consensus view the early 2020s. Since late 2023, market expectations for Gas Turbine structural growth have turned more constructive. While orders continue to reach new records, margin is yet to catch up, as is typical in such a "long- cycle" business. Historically, underlying EBITA margin can move comfortably into double digits in up cycles. In 2002- 03, EBITA margins reached \(\sim 16\%\) ; post the GFC, the up cycle saw margins climb to almost \(18\%\) (Exhibit 8).
Exhibit 7: Global Gas Turbine Orders (in GW)
Source: McCoy, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 8: Historical Siemens Gas & Power Adj. EBITA Margin

Power transmission and distribution equipment is another "long- cycle" business. Historically under Siemens and ABB, Grid has seen margin upswings of \(5 - 10\%\) in upcycles. In 2003- 2008, Siemens PTD margin rose from \(2\%\) to \(10\%\) , while ABB PTD margin rose from \(6\%\) to \(14\%\) .
Exhibit 9: Power Transmission and Distribution historical margin
Source: Company Data, Morgan Stanley Research

The 2025e Global Gas turbine market is running hot. The latest 2Q25 gas turbine data (McCoy) shows gas turbine orders reached 21.3GW in 2Q25. We show the order level versus recent history in Exhibit 11, and this is \(56\%\) higher than the 20- year quarterly average of 13GW. The market is now annualising at \(\sim 83GW\) , and is tracking to be the best year since 2007 (82GW) and also \(57\%\) higher than the 20- year average of 52GW.

These are levels not seen since 2001 (Exhibit 13) and to put the current ordering level into context ( \(>80GW\) ), actual Gas turbine deliveries are on track to reach 50GW in 2025 (Exhibit 15). This implies an industry book:bill of 1.66x. Based on announced capacity expansions, we think that industry capacity is on track to reach 65GW in 2028. This suggests favourable supply/demand dynamics will persist on a three- year view and support gas turbine pricing further.

Regionally, North America was the most significant driver of 1H25 Gas turbine orders, accounting for around half of the industry orders. This is in contrast to the last four quarters, when the Middle East and Asia were more significant drivers (see Exhibit 12). We see a high likelihood of Germany becoming a bigger driver of demand in 2026.

In terms of market share, historically the market has been dominated by 3 players: GE Vernova, Siemens Energy and Mitsubishi Power (Exhibit 10). What stands out in 1H25 is Siemens Energy's increase in market share to \(40\%\) in 1H25, above historical levels (25- 33%). The company has demonstrated that it is well positioned to participate in North America's data centre growth.

Market dynamics are reflected in company orders. Through 2Q25 results, we have seen orders beat consensus expectations at Siemens Energy Gas services, GE Vernova Power, and Mitsubishi HI's Energy. Siemens Energy's Gas services orders were \(+22\%\) YoY, GEV's Power division orders were \(+44\%\) YoY, and Mitsubishi Energy systems orders were \(+8\%\) YoY. Reassuringly, strength is not just coming from the new equipment market, and GE Vernova's Power aftermarket orders grew by \(+4\%\) , while Siemens Energy's Gas services aftermarket revenues grew at \(+9\%\) in fiscal 3Q25 (calendar 2Q25).

**Exhibit 10:** Gas Turbine market share by company: Siemens Energy has increased its market share in 1H25 versus prior years, and participated in the US (DC) opportunity to a greater extent than the market expected. While market share may level off in 2H25 and 2026, we think market dynamics give the Siemens Gas services division attractive visibility out to the end of the decade, with a clear runway for EBITA margins to keep surprising positively

The global grid equipment market remains relatively fragmented but it is growing, especially in Asia and the US. Strong demand combined with supply chain bottlenecks (lead times, capacity constraints) have increased margins by \(\sim 100bps\) vs historical averages. However, we see capacity increases and a potential flattening in European grid spending demand as drivers for margin normalization for medium voltage into 2H26 and into 2027, followed by high voltage margins peaking in 2028.

A fragmented global grid equipment market. In 2024, Hitachi, Siemens Energy and GE Vernova generated \(\sim \epsilon 30bn\) in sales, which we estimate equates to a combined market share of 25- 30%. Asia- Pacific is an important region for grid equipment. There are large

companies such as TBEA that are primarily focused on the domestic China market, but also others that are more international. For example, Fortune Electric (Taiwan, not covered) and Hyundai (South Korea, covered by Ryan Kim) will likely both have \(>50\%\) of sales overseas in 2025e.

Demand is shaped by regional grid spending. Morgan Stanley's European Utilities team forecasts Grid capex will double in 2030 vs 2023 (Exhibit 16), with transmission capex growing at a \(15\%\) CAGR and Distribution at \(5\%\) (LINK). In the US, Bloomberg New Energy Finance forecast US transformer demand (units) to be \(65\%\) higher in 2027, compared to 2023 (Exhibit 18) and US Transmission Network Capex is expected to grow at a \(5.5\%\) CAGR to 2027 and Distribution at \(4\%\) CAGR (Exhibit 19). There is a debate on European grid capex beyond 2030: TenneT, one of the major German TSOs, forecasts a moderation in capex spending into the 2030s (see Exhibit 17). This would further accelerate a normalization in HV margins back to the historical range (5- 10%).

Supply dynamics continue favouring margins. 1) Lead times on transformers remain high. Depending on transformer type, lead times increased from 40- 80 weeks at the start of 2022 to 120 weeks by the end of 2023. However, what we heard from companies signals that Transformer lead times may be even higher than this, e.g., at 2- 3 years for Fortune Electric, with the European suppliers facing lead times that are higher still. (2) Prices have started to stabilize at levels in 2024 that are 80- 90% higher than 2020 levels (Exhibit 20). Capacity is being added, but it takes time. Hitachi appears to be doubling transformer capacity, and Fortune Electric's capacity is also likely to have doubled by 2027. High voltage capacity additions should continue to bring down lead times for transformers as new capacity comes on line in 2027. Siemens Energy's annual grid sales are typically made up of \(50\%\) products (1- 2 year lead times) and \(50\%\) solutions (where orders may be booked in 2028 or beyond). (3) Some of the Asia Grid equipment companies (Fortune and Hyundai) are already now reporting EBIT margins that are \(>20\%\) in the last couple of quarters. We think this is due in part to a higher share of products in their revenue mix (and less solutions), and also because these products are turning through the backlog faster than solutions which tend to be longer- dated in the backlogs of Siemens Energy.

Looking ahead – High voltage margins: Siemens Energy's high voltage margins have operated in a 5- 15% range, versus our forecast of 18% in 2028. Our forecasts for Siemens Energy now reflect 2028 being peak margin for the grid technologies division. We are hearing comments from high voltage equipment companies (e.g. GEV) that global grid pricing is still positive, but at a less positive rate than in 2023/24. Also, European price increases have become more of a challenge on new orders (Exhibit 21).

**Exhibit 16:** European Electrical Networks capex: Our Utilities team forecast this to double between 2023 and 2030. The UK (National Grid) and Germany (TSOs) are important drivers of this. We think that the plans out to 2028 are broadly supported by already approved projects, but there is a debate whether capex is sustainable at these levels next decade
European Electricity Networks Capex (MSe, €bn)
Source: Morgan Stanley Research estimates
Exhibit 17: TenneT capex plans: TenneT highlights the expectation of a step- down in capex beyond 2030. Grid infrastructure are long- lasting assets and once built can last 30- 40 years in many cases

Exhibit 19: US Transformer supply gap (units): This implies that a considerable amount of future transformer demand in the US will need to be served by imports. For this reason, we are less concerned about the capacity increases that are coming on globally
Source: BNEF, DOE, Trade map, Bloomberg estimates, Morgan Stanley Research

**Exhibit 20:** Electrical Equipment producer price inflation: Transformers and medium voltage switchgears have seen significant price inflation, but the rate of increase appears to have moderated. Currently, there are some instances of higher prices becoming prohibitive for HV projects, then new capacity (HV and MV) will be added, and then grid investment may step down into the 2030s. But, we think timing the margin normalization will be key across the sub-segments
Source: Datastream, Morgan Stanley Research

Siemens Energy has attractive revenue visibility in Gas turbine and Grid from the strong order backlog. We also expect that favourable supply demand in these industries will lead to 2028 EBITA margins surprising to the upside. The wind turnaround is ongoing, but we see very little value ascribed to the wind business implied in Siemens Energy's sum of the parts currently, and see this as a potential source of upside. The stock has performed well year to date, but still trades on around half of the multiple of GE Vernova. FCF yield in 2028e also remains attractive at \(\sim 6\%\) .
Source: Refinitiv, Morgan Stanley Research
Renewable Energy: Positive Secular Growth: Positive

The probabilities of our Bull, Base, and Bear case scenarios playing out were estimated with implied volatility data from the options market as of 27 Aug 2025. All figures are approximate risk- neutral probabilities of the stock reaching beyond the scenario price in either three- months' or one- years' time. View explanation of Options Probabilities methodology here

In our bull case we assume Siemens Energy's sales grow at a 15% CAGR in 2024- 28. We assume a group EBITA margin of 15.6% in 2028 (20% for Gas services, 20% for Grid Tech). This yields a 2028 bull case EBITA of €9.5bn vs €7.75bn in our base case. We apply 12x 2028e EV/EBITA to our 2028 forecast.
In our base case we forecast organic revenue CAGR of 12% in 2024- 28. We also assume a 14.2% EBITA margin by 2028. This implies 1.7x our base case 2028e EV/Sales.

In our bear case, we assume Siemens Energy grows at an \(\sim 8\%\) CAGR, which would be slower than expected in our base case given the backlog. We assume a 12% 2028 EBITA margin and apply a 1.2x EV/Sales multiple to our 2028 forecasts. This implies Siemens Energy trades on an implied 2028e EV/EBITA of 10x.
